overview.short: Brucella abortus is a small, Gram-negative, non-motile coccobacillus primarily associated with cattle and capable of causing zoonotic brucellosis in humans.
overview.clinical_context: Human infections typically occur via contact with infected livestock or consumption of unpasteurised dairy products.

species_markers.notes: H₂S production distinguishes B. abortus from B. melitensis and B. suis.
Some strains require added CO₂ for growth, unlike other Brucella species.
Primary animal reservoir; useful epidemiological clue.

common_confusions.reason: Close genetic relationship may cause misidentification in automated systems.

when_to_question_identification: Lack of H₂S production may indicate B. melitensis.
Rapid growth without CO₂ may suggest B. suis or misidentification.
Motility or fermentation reactions are inconsistent with Brucella.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Differentiates B. abortus from other Brucella species.
Some strains require CO₂ supplementation for growth.
Confirmatory and safe for high-risk pathogens.
